definition:
Let $V$ be a representation of a Lie algebra ${\mathfrak{g}}$ over a
field $k$. Then a bilinear form $B:V\times V\to k$ is [*invariant*]{} if
$$B(Xv,w)+B(v,Xw)=0.$$ for all $X\in{\mathfrak{g}}, v,w\in V$. This
criterion seems a little odd, but in the context of Lie algebras, it
makes sense. For example, the map $\tilde{B}:V\to V^*$ given by
$v\mapsto B(\cdot,v)$ is equivariant if and only if $B$ is an invariant
form.
